BE11:15am

RELX, the owner of Elsevier academic journals, slipped after contract renewal talks broke down with University of California, which said it would its subscriptions. The university, whose campuses represent about 10 per cent of all academic publishing in the US, said Elsevier was “unwilling to meet UC’s key goal: securing universal open access to UC research while containing the rapidly escalating costs associated with for-profit journals”.

The UC has long been a proponent of so-called “publish and read” deals, where open-access publishing fees are bundled with subscription access in one payment. The loss of UC was likely to be modest to RELX’s earnings — the university was reportedly paying around $11m per year for journals access, representing about 0.3 per cent of divisional revenue — but investors saw the news as raising the risk of other academic consortia following. Germany’s Projekt Deal group has already moved to reject for-profit subscriptions while Elsevier has contracts in France, the Netherlands, Norway and Hungary all up for renewal.

Analysts estimated that RELX takes about 40 per cent of group earnings from academic publishing, about half of which comes from journals. “The major risk is contagion,” said Citigroup. RELX faces “something of a prisoners’ dilemma: by holding out in individual cases it risks aggravating the [open access[ movement while giving in for one will almost certainly mean giving in for all. The risk is to the [valuation] multiple.”

BE11:23am

At the heart of the dispute is the UC's insistence that its authors' articles published in Elsevier journals will be distributed for free and with no extra charge paid by the UC system. While seemingly innocuous, this would potentially offer a significant risk to the Elsevier subscription model. Given that research is concentrated among the major universities, if the latter demanded that their content be made available to all for free under the terms of their contracts, then - very quickly - most of the world's articles would effectively be available for free, undermining the scientific publishing model. It is therefore no wonder Elsevier has stood its grounds.

BE11:23am

There are two questions here:

(1) How much this impacts numbers. We estimate academic journals alone are probably worth c. 20% of group profits. The recent FY18 results showed the Elsevier showing its same +2% organic revenue growth it has done, with academic journals above that. Elsevier has made the point that it has c. 12K contracts worldwide and that the disputed contracts publicised were only 5-6 of these. However, not all contracts are the same and the UC contract would have been one of their biggest. Nevertheless, our overall conclusion is this will not change the numbers that much (although it may impact the ability of Elsevier's organic revenue growth to accelerate from 2% to 3%). The fact is that Elsevier has been focusing its attention on higher growth areas such as database and tools which are generating high single digit / double digit organic revenue and this is likely to maintain the +2%.

(2) how much does this encourage other universities to take a similar line. That would presumably be the issue for Elsevier as UC's very open move could encourage others to follow suit.

Our view is that, in terms of numbers, Elsevier will handle this as it will be able to absorb the impact. The issue more though is about the impact on the rating given the high relative valuation of RELX and this is where we expect most of the share price impact to be concentrated.

Tesla CEO Elon Musk explained that in order for the company to be able to both offer the car at this low a price and to remain financially
sustainable, it has become necessary to close most of the company’s well over one hundred stores, which we estimate could result in another round of potentially thousands of lay-offs (it dismissed 7% of its full-time staff just last month), along with restructuring charges and severance pay. We do not think this was the original plan envisaged by Tesla management and bullish investors, but rather is instead suggestive of what we have long feared — that the Model 3 would prove more difficult and more expensive to manufacture than was originally projected, such that the firm would struggle to earn its targeted above industry average 25% gross margin as it transitions toward industry average pricing. And why would Tesla today be able to generate substantially above industry average gross margin on mass-market models, given it lacks the purchasing power and the ability to amortize fixed development costs across as many units as its much larger global automaker peers, and given the added cost of electric propulsion? We estimate that because manufacturing costs have tracked higher than expected, the firm has had to turn to deep and unplanned cuts to SG&A in order to make up the difference.

BE11:40am

Specifically, the ~20% margin on the current Model 3 [ASP in 4Q of $45,000] implies a gross profit/vehicle of $9000 and COGS of $34000. And with a likely 50kWh battery pack [70% of the 75kWh pack for 70% of the range], the 25k battery pack savings at $100/kWh would only be $2500, bring COGS down to $31,500. Assume $1500 for lower cost interiors could reduce COGS to ~$30,000, implying 14% gross margins and $5000/car contribution, versus Mr. Musk’s forecasts for greater than 25% gross margins from the Model 3 at some point in 2019 [which he claimed did include the lower priced variant at some point].

Pharma @luzh, physics is something of a special case, as everyone works together (there is only one CERN), and conclusions are externally testable.Not sure it will work in bioscience, where pissing off a powerful competitor could ruin your career, and without seeing the raw data, you have no way of knowing if it is true or not.
Soundbuy *takeover
BE11:40am

While cutting SGA by $1.5bn (6% of our estimated $25bn revenue) will help offset some of the impact, we wonder about the impact on demand. While less-affluent Tesla fans on the waitlist will likely rush to reserve the lower cost model and will not be put off by lack of sales outlets, beyond that cohort Tesla’s challenge is to ‘cross the chasm’ and attract a broader buyer base beyond the early adopters. We wonder how many of these will be willing to buy a car without a test drive (even with a 7-day return policy).

It again stresses that H1 will be tough. Organic revenue growth for 2019 w is likely to split c-3% in H1 and -1% in H2. There is no indication on January trading.
WPP is guiding to a margin down c100bps in 2019 at 14.3%.On a pre associates basis we are on a margin of 14.3% (css 14.4%) in 2019. WPP indicated in December that it aims not to fall beneath a margin of 14% on this basis in 2019.
This implies that 2019 eps will be likely in the range of 95p-99p. Consensus is at 99.6p , MSe at 96.5p.

BE12:15pm

2H18 clean PBT of $98m is roughly inline with MSe and consensus. Net
revenues of $423m is 4% ahead of MSe driven by stronger than expected
performance fees of $44m (vs. Mse $22m). Revenue beat is offset by a higher cost print at $326m (vs. Mse $311m). Management fee PBT of $97m was ~1% ahead of consensus with perf. fees PBT of $1m inline with MSe.
Flow beat driven by strength in total return. Q4'18 AUM of $108.5bn is ~1%
better than consensus and MSe mainly due to better net flows (NNM of ~7% vs MSe at ~4%) and slightly better performance. Strong flows into total return was largely driven by flows into alternative risk premia. However, given this is a ~60bps margin product, overall group revenue margins falls to ~70bps from ~75bp in FY17.
Risk to consensus FY19 estimates. Although the company sees a healthy
number of new mandate wins, they also say that they are seeing a pick up in redemptions. We see risk to consensus FY19 flow expectations of ~$4.9bn and risk to group revenue margins forecasts given relative strength in lower margin products (Total return and long only).

Man Group has released FY18 results to 31 Dec 2018. Group adj. PBT
of $251m (FY17 $384m) was in line our estimate of $251m. The
decline YoY was driven by significantly lower perf fee PBT of $34m
(vs. FY17 $181m) whilst management fee PBT increased from $203m
to $217m. Group AUM during Q418 declined by 5% to $108.5bn
(JPME $107.6bn), reflecting stronger net inflows of +$2.1bn vs. our
est. of +$0.5bn offset by negative investment perf/FX of -$7.6bn (vs.
JPME -$7bn). The 2018 DPS was increased by 9% to 11.8c (JPMe
11.5c) with surplus capital of $340m (c11% of mcap). The outlook is
mixed with the company citing healthy new mandate wins, as well as a
pick-up in redemptions. We expect a moderation in FY19 consensus
estimates reflecting the lower closing AUM, reduced net management
fee run-rate of 69bps, and higher fixed costs.

David McCann at Numis sets out the case much better than I can, so I'm going to overquote him. Apologies to him and them.

wayneJ @FatDaz - Jupiter is already 17% owned by Silchester
BE12:22pm

Adjusted EPS at 31.7p was in line with our est. 31.8p and consensus 31.6p. More importantly, there are several favourable pieces of other news: 1) Management have found a way of mitigating the negative regulatory capital impact that was expected from the adoption of IFRS16, by changing the calculation methodology used. Consequently the dividend will be paid at a broadly unchanged 90% total payout ratio and surplus capital has actually slightly increased. 2) The revenue margin held up better than we had feared in H2. 3) Management have taken actions that will "lower run rate costs in 2019." Our FY19/20 EPS forecasts increase by +11%, of which this change in cost outlook is the main driver. 4) We calculate that Dynamic Bond saw net inflows in February (albeit the group as a whole was still net flow negative due to other funds).

BE12:22pm

We believe #1-3 remove a reasonable degree of short term uncertainty that we feel had been overhanging the shares. #4 is a positive development in our view, albeit still perhaps a little early to conclude that this is a permanent turnaround and noting that the overall group position is still negative. We further note that the medium to long term strategic outlook/direction remains uncertain whilst we wait to hear from the new CEO (who only starts today) and whilst a new CFO is recruited.

FATDAZ @waynej thanks
12:22 pm
BE12:22pm

In light of the mainly favourable short term news, we upgrade our recommendation from Hold to Add. We feel that a reasonable amount of shorter term uncertainty has been removed by today's update. However, we also note that short term flows remain unpredictable and we do not yet know in what direction new management might take the company over the medium-long term, hence we do not feel it is appropriate at this stage to upgrade to an "fully fledged" buy recommendation, but we have turned positive nonetheless.
